greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least prime p such that sigma(x)=sigma(p) has exactly n solutions.
comment: For 1<n<258, we have a(n)=11 (mod 12). Is this true for all n>1? It also appears that for each n there are an infinite number of primes p such that sigma(x)=sigma(p) has exactly n solutions.
link: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1199
mathematica: s=DivisorSigma[1, Range[100000]]; t=Table[Length[Position[s, Prime[n]+1]], {n, PrimePi[Length[s]]}]; u=Union[t]; nLast=First[Complement[Range[u[[ -1]]], u]]-1; Flatten[Table[Prime[Position[t, n, 1, 1]], {n, nLast}]]
program: (PARI) sigv(n) =  select(i->sigma(i) == n, vector(n, i, i));
a(n) = {p = 2; while (#(sigv(p+1))! = n, p = nextprime(p+1)); p;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, May 01 2014
xref: Cf. A007368 (least k such that sigma(x)=k has n solutions), A066075 (number of solutions to sigma(x)=sigma(prime(n))).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Jan 21 2006
